1,3,5-Tris(3,5-dibromophenyl)benzene (1): 1-(3,5-Dibromophenyl)ethanone (5.56 g, 20 mmol) was dissolved in 20 mL of EtOH and the mixture was kept at 0 oC. SOCl2 (7.5 mL) was added dropwise slowly to mixture at 0 oC and then the reaction was stirred vigorously at reflux for 4 h. After cooling to room temperature, the reaction was quenched slowly by saturated NaHCO3 and then EtOH was added to form large amount of yellow solid. The solid (3.88 g, 74.6% yield) was washed alternately with DCM and EtOH, and collected, dried under vacuum. 1H NMR (400 MHz, CDCl3, 298.15 K) 汛 [ppm]: 7.72 (s, 9H), 7.65 (s, 3H). 13C NMR (101 MHz, CDCl3, 298.15 K) 汛 [ppm]: 143.81, 140.42, 133.60, 129.32, 126.11, 123.70.  Compound 2: A Schlenk flask charged with 1,3-dibromobenzene (5.19 g, 22.0 mmol), (3-((tert-butoxycarbonyl)amino)phenyl)boronic acid (3.92 g, 16.5 mmol), Pd(PPh3)4 (1.02 g, 0.88 mmol), and potassium carbonate (12.16 g, 88.0 mmol) was purged with N2 for three times, and then 160 mL of 1,4-dioxane and 40 mL of water were added under nitrogen atmosphere. The reaction mixture was stirred at 90 oC for 12 h. Organic solvent was removed under reduced pressure and the residue was extracted with DCM (3 ∩ 100 mL) and washed with brine (100 mL), dried over MgSO4. The crude product was purified by column chromatography on silica gel with EtOAc/PE = 1/10 (v/v) to yield a white solid (3.37 g, 56.9% yield). 1H NMR (400 MHz, CDCl3, 298.15 K) 汛 [ppm]: 7.72 (s, 1H), 7.63 (s, 1H), 7.50 (d, J = 8.0 Hz, 1H), 7.46 (d, S7  J = 8.0 Hz, 1H), 7.35 (m, J = 7.6 Hz, 1H), 7.33 (br, 1H), 7.29 (d, J = 8.0 Hz, 1H), 7.22 (d, J = 7.2 Hz, 1H), 6.58 (s, 1H), 1.54 (s, 9H). 13C NMR (101 MHz, CDCl3, 298.15 K) 汛 [ppm]: 152.83, 143.17, 140.79, 139.04, 130.46, 130.34, 129.60, 125.99, 122.94, 121.96, 118.03, 117.31, 80.85, 28.49.  Compound 3: Into a 500 mL Schlenk flask were charged 2 (3.37 g, 9.68 mmol), bis(pinacolato)diboron (2.46 g, 9.69 mmol), Pd(dppf)Cl2 (0.35 g, 0.48 mmol), and potassium acetate (4.75 g, 48.40 mmol). The flask was degassed with N2 for three times, in which 100 mL of 1,4-dioxane was added then. The reaction mixture was stirred at 90 oC for 12 h. Organic solvent was removed under reduced pressure and the residue was extracted with DCM (3 ∩ 100 mL) and washed with brine (100 mL). The organic phase was collected together and dried over MgSO4, concentrated under reduced pressure. The crude residue was purified by column chromatography on silica gel with EtOAc/PE = 1/10 (v/v) to yield a white solid (3.00 g, 78.3% yield). 1H NMR (400 MHz, CDCl3, 298.15 K) 汛 [ppm]: 8.02 (s, 1H), 7.78 (d, J = 7.2 Hz, 1H), 7.68 (d, J = 8.0 Hz, 1H), 7.54 (s, 1H), 7.43 (t, J = 7.6 Hz, 1H), 7.40 (br, 1H), 7.35(t, J = 7.6 Hz, 1H), 7.30 (d, J = 7.6 Hz, 1H), 6.59 (s, 1H), 1.53 (s, 9H), 1.36 (s, 12H). 13C NMR (101 MHz, CDCl3, 298.15 K) 汛 [ppm]: 152.90, 142.20, 140.31, 138.81, 133.96, 133.63, 130.22, 129.44, 128.28, 122.24, 117.51, 84.01, 67.24, 28.52, 25.04.

Compound 4: Into a 100 mL Schlenk flask were charged compound 1 (0.78 g, 1.0 mmol), compound 3 (2.85 g, 7.2 mmol), Pd(PPh3)4 (0.35 g, 0.30 mmol), and potassium S8  carbonate (4.15 g, 30.0 mmol). The flask was degassed with N2 for three times, in which 40 mL of 1,4-dioxane and 10 mL of water were added then. The reaction mixture was stirred at 90 oC for 24 h. Organic solvent was removed under reduced pressure and the residue was extracted with DCM (3 ∩ 50 mL) and washed with brine (50 mL). The organic phase was collected together and dried over MgSO4, concentrated under reduced pressure. The crude residue was purified by column chromatography on silica gel with EtOAc/PE = 1/2 (v/v) to yield a yellow solid (1.34 g, 70.1% yield). 1H NMR (400 MHz, CDCl3, 298.15 K) 汛 [ppm]: 8.04 (s, 3H), 7.96 (s, 6H), 7.90 (s, 3H), 7.87 (s, 6H), 7.70 (d, J = 6.4 Hz, 6H), 7.60 (s, 6 H),7.59 (s, 6H), 7.52 (t, J = 6.2 Hz, 6H), 7.37 (br, 6H), 7.34 (t, J = 6.0 Hz, 6H), 7.31 (d, J = 6.0 Hz, 6H), 6.59 (s, 6H), 1.49 (s, 54H). 13C NMR (101 MHz, CDCl3, 298.15 K) 汛 [ppm]: 152.89, 142.95, 142.85, 142.74, 142.48, 142.07, 141.76, 141.63, 138.93, 129.57, 129.43, 126.71, 126.47, 126.21, 125.95, 125.86, 122.18, 117.73, 117.53, 80.70, 28.47.

Compound 5: TFA (15 mL) was added dropwise to a DCM solution (30 mL) of compound 4 (1.34 g, 0.70 mmol) at ice bath. The reaction mixture was stirred at 25 oC for 12 h and then quenched by saturated NaHCO3 until pH = 8?9. The residue was extracted with DCM (3 ∩ 50 mL) and washed with brine (50 mL). The organic phase was collected together and dried over MgSO4, concentrated under reduced pressure to yield a yellow solid (0.84 g, 91.4% yield). 1H NMR (400 MHz, CDCl3, 298.15 K) 汛 [ppm]: 8.05 (s, 3H), 7.98 (s, 6H), 7.92 (s, 3H), 7.89 (s, 6H), 7.69 (d, J = 7.6 Hz, 6H), 7.58 (d, J = 7.6 Hz, 6H), 7.52 (t, J = 7.6 Hz, 6H), 7.21 (t, J = 8.0 Hz, 6H), 7.04 (d, J = 7.6 Hz, 6H), 6.96 (s, 6H), 6.67 (dd, J = 8.0, 2.0 Hz, 6H), 3.69 (br, 12H). 13C NMR (101 S9  MHz, CDCl3, 298.15 K) 汛 [ppm]: 146.92, 142.87, 142.80, 142.45, 142.39, 142.25, 141.56, 129.89, 129.36, 126.58, 126.50, 126.44, 126.17, 125.92, 125.78, 117.91, 114.40, 114.09.  2,4,6-Trihydroxybenzene-1,3,5-tricarbaldehyde (TP): Phloroglucinol (2.00 g, 15.9 mmol) and formamidine acetate (8.25 g, 79.4 mmol) were combined in 200 mL of THF in a round-bottom flask. At 45 oC acetic anhydride (14.7 mL, 159.0 mmol) was added, and the reaction allowed to proceed for 24 h. The reaction was worked up by evaporating THF solvent and leftover acetic anhydride under reduced pressure at 50 oC, followed by stirring in water (200 mL) at 45 oC for 2 h. Aqueous LiOH (3 mol?L?1, 400 mL, 1200 mmol) was added slowly, then stirring continued for 20 h. Aqueous hydrochloric acid was added to re-acidify the solution to pH = 3每4, causing a light red powder to precipitate. The precipitate was extracted with CHCl3 (3 ∩ 100 mL) and dried over MgSO4, decolored by active carbon. The organic phase was collected by filtration and concentrated to yield a light grey powder (0.99 g, 30.0% yield). 1H NMR (400 MHz, DMSO-d6, 298.15 K) 汛 [ppm]: 9.98 (s, 3H), 5.01 (br, 3H). 13C NMR (101 MHz, DMSO-d6, 298.15 K) 汛 [ppm]: 191.47, 173.38, 103.21.

Synthesis of Diphane-5: In a dried round-bottom flask, to a THF solution (70 mL) of compound 5 (0.84 g, 0.64 mmol) and Sc(OTf)3 (98 mg, 0.2 mmol) was added S10  dropwise TP (0.27 g, 1.28 mmol) dissolved in 140 mL of THF. The reaction mixture was stirred at 25 oC for 48 h. After filtration and concentration, the residue was purified by column chromatography on silica gel with THF/hexane = 2/1(v/v) to yield a yellow solid (45 mg, 4.4% yield). The yellow solid was dissolved in CHCl3 and successively precipitated in non-solvents, including MeOH, acetone, and diethyl ether. Then, the precipitate (mainly composed of configuration-1) was collected by centrifugation. NMR data for configuration-1: 1H NMR (500 MHz, C2D2Cl4, 298.15 K) 汛 [ppm]: 12.84 (d, J = 13.0 Hz, 6H), 8.47 (d, J = 13.0 Hz, 6H), 8.14 (s, 3H), 8.09 (s, 6H), 8.07 (s, 3H), 8.02 (s, 6H), 7.83 (d, J = 8.0 Hz, 6H), 7.76 (d, J = 7.5 Hz, 6H), 7.60 (d, J = 8.5 Hz, 6H), 7.58 (s, 9H), 7.56 (t, J = 7.5 Hz, 6H), 7.45 (t, J = 8.0 Hz, 6H), 7.18 (d, J = 7.5 Hz, 6H). 13C NMR (126 MHz, C2D2Cl4, 298.15 K) 汛 [ppm]: 184.96, 151.35, 142.95, 141.34, 141.23, 141.12, 140.63, 140.12, 139.62, 138.88, 129.98, 129.77, 125.53, 125.21, 125.13, 124.76, 123.74, 120.77, 118.37, 108.46. MALDI-TOF-MS of Diphane-5 (m/z): calculated for C114H72N6O6 1622.563 [M+H]+, found 1622.313 [M+H]+.  Synthesis of TSAN: A mixture of TP (0.16 g, 0.76 mmol) and aniline (0.49 mL, 5.37 mmol) was suspended in 70 mL of ethanol, and heated to reflux for 24 h. After cooling to room temperature, the precipitate was collected by filtration, washed with anhydrous ethanol, and dried under vacuum to yield a yellow solid (0.29 g, 87.5% yield). 1H NMR (400 MHz, C2D2Cl4, 298.15 K) 汛 [ppm]: 13.33 (d, J = 13.2 Hz, =CNH), 13.23 (d, J = 13.2 Hz, =CNH), 13.03 (d, J = 13.2 Hz, =CNH), 12.99 (d, J = 13.2 Hz, =CNH), 8.84 (d, J = 13.2 Hz, HC?N), 8.83 (d, J = 13.2 Hz, HC?N), 8.78 (d, J = 13.2 Hz, HC?N), 8.76 (d, J = 13.2 Hz, HC?N), 7.40?7.51 (m, Ph), 7.28?7.40 (m, Ph), 7.20?7.28 (m, Ph). 13C NMR (101 MHz, C2D2Cl4, 298.15 K) 汛 [ppm]: 187.92, 185.21, 185.19, 182.23, 150.05, 149.48, 149.38, 148.59, 138.72, 129.79, 125.74, 125.65, 117.75, 117.62, S11  117.53, 106.62, 106.59, 106.48.  S12  4. Determination of Accurate Structures of Diphane-5 4.1 Discussion on Possible Isomers in Diphane-5 To enumerate all possible isomers of Diphane-5, we considered two factors contributing to its isomerization: configuration (cis-trans isomerism of C=C bond) and conformation (rotation of phenyl pillars of Diphane-5).

Ed.  2024, e202405858Link to VoR: https://doi.org/10.1002/anie.202405858  1 Unraveling the Dynamic Molecular Motions of a Twin-Cavity Cage with Slow Configurational but Rapid Conformational Interconversions Yong Zuo+[a], Zhenghong Chen+[a], Ziying Li+[b], Enguang Fu[a], Yonghang Xin[a], Chenhao Chen[a], Chenfei Li*[a], and Shaodong Zhang*[a] [a]School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Shanghai Jiao Tong University, 800 Dongchuan Road, Shanghai, 200240, China.  [b]Shanghai Center for Systems Biomedicine, Key Laboratory of Systems Biomedicine (Ministry of Education), Shanghai Jiao Tong University, 800 Dongchuan Road, Shanghai, 200240, China. +Y. Zuo, Z. Chen and Z. Li equally contributed to this work. *Email: chenfeili@sjtu.edu.cn; sdzhang@sjtu.edu.cn Abstract Featuring diverse structural motions/changes, dynamic molecular systems hold promise for executing complex tasks. However, their structural complexity presents formidable challenge in elucidating their kinetics, especially when multiple structural motions are intercorrelated. We herein introduce a twin-cavity cage that features interconvertible C3- and C1-configurations, each configuration exhibiting interchangeable P- and M-conformations. This molecule is therefore composed of four interconnected chiral species (P)-C3, (M)-C3, (P)-C1, (M)-C1. We showcase an effective methodology to decouple these sophisticated structural changes into two kinetically distinct pathways. Utilizing time-dependent 1H NMR spectroscopy at various temperatures, which disregards the transition between mirror-image conformations, we first determine the rate constant (kc) for C3- to C1-configuration interconversion; while time-dependent circular dichroism spectroscopy at different temperatures quantifies the observed rate constant (kobs) of ensemble of all structural changes. As kobs >> kc, it allows us to decouple the overall molecular motions into a slow configurational transformation and rapid conformational interconversions, the latter further dissected into two independent 10.1002/anie.202405858Accepted ManuscriptAngewandte Chemie International EditionThis article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Materials Reagents and solvents were purchased from commercial suppliers and used without further purification, unless other indicated. 1-(3,5-Dibromophenyl)ethanone, (3-((tert-butoxycarbonyl)amino)phenyl)boronic acid and catalysts tetrakis-(triphenylphosphine)-palladium [Pd(PPh3)4] and [1,1＊-bis(diphenylphosphino)-ferrocene]dichloropalladium(II) [Pd(dppf)Cl2] were purchased from Bidepharm, China. Bis(pinacolato)diboron ((Bpin)2), 1,3-dibromobenzene, phloroglucinol, formamidine acetate, trifluoroacetic acid (TFA), scandium(III) trifluoromethanesulfonate [Sc(OTf)3] were purchased from Adamas-beta, China. Thionylchloride (SOCl2), and inorganic salts including potassium carbonate, potassium acetate, sodium bicarbonate and magnesium sulfate were purchased from Greagent, China. Flash column chromatography was performed on silica gel (200每300 mesh) and the compounds were visualized under 254 nm on thin-layer chromatography (TLC) plates.  2. Techniques 2.1 Nuclear Magnetic Resonance (NMR) 1H and 13C NMR spectra were recorded on a Bruker A VANCE III HD 400, Bruker AVANCE III HD 500, or Bruker A VANCE NEO 700 NMR spectrometer. 1H and 13C NMR spectra were measured at 298.15 K in CDCl3, C2D2Cl4 or DMSO-d6. Their proton and 13carbon residuals are used as internal references for 1H and 13C NMR, respectively. Proton chemical shifts (汛) are reported in ppm and coupling constants (J) in Hertz (Hz). The multiplicity in the 1H NMR spectra are described as s (singlet); d (doublet); dd (doublet of doublets); t (triplet); q (quartet); m (multiplet); br (broad). Time-dependent 1H NMR spectra were recorded in C2D2Cl4 at different temperatures on a Bruker AVANCE III HD 500 spectrometer with different time intervals. Quantitative 13C NMR spectrum was measured in C2D2Cl4 at 298.15 K on a Bruker AVANCE NEO 700 NMR spectrometer, employing 1024 scans and a relaxation delay (D1) of 15 s following the addition of relaxation reagent chromium(III) acetylacetonate. S4  2.2 Matrix-Assisted Laser Desorption/Ionization Time of Flight (MALDI-TOF) Mass Spectrometry MALDI-TOF mass spectrometry was performed on a Bruker Autoflex speed TOF/TOF mass spectrometer and operated in reflective mode. Internal calibration was performed using peptide (700?3500 Dalton) as standards. The analytical samples were obtained by mixing the CHCl3 solution of the sample (5 mg mL?1) and CH2Cl2 solution of the matrix (trans-2-[3-(4-tert-butylphenyl)-2-methyl-2-propene]-malononitrile (DCTB, 10 mg mL?1) in a 1/5 (v/v) ratio. The prepared mixture solution of the sample (1 米L) was loaded on the MALDI-TOF plate and allowed to dry at room temperature before the plate was inserted into the vacuum chamber of the MALDI-TOF instrument. 2.3 Single Crystal X-Ray Diffractometry (SC-XRD) The single crystal data of configuration-1 of Diphane-5 was collected on Bruker D8 VENTURE. The structure was solved by direct methods using the OLEX-2 software. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined using anisotropic thermal parameters. The refined single crystal data are listed in Table S10. 2.4 Circular Dichroism (CD) Circular dichroism (CD) spectroscopy was performed with a JASCO J-1500 spectrometer. Time-dependent CD spectra were performed in C2D2Cl4 at various temperatures and different time intervals, utilizing 1 mm quartz cuvettes. The experimental conditions included a scan rate of 500 nm﹞min?1, a response time of 1 s and a bandwidth of 5 nm.  2.5 Density Functional Theory (DFT) All calculations were executed using the Gaussian 16 A.03 program[S1] with default procedures, algorithms and integration grids. The initial structure, derived from single crystal analysis, underwent optimization employing the hybrid functional B3LYP[S2?S5] coupled with the 6-31G(d,p) basis level.[S6?S8]  To determine the valid thermodynamic potential for different isomers (at 298.15 K, 1.0 atm), we conducted vibrational frequency calculations using optimized molecular S5  geometry, simulating the solvent 1,2-dichloroethane within the SMD framework. Specifically, frequency calculations were performed at the B3LYP/6-31G(d,p) level[S6?S8]. Additionally, to identify possible transition states during the interconversion between the C3- and C1-configurations resulting from the rotation of the carbon-carbon bond, we conducted transition state searches by employing the Berny geometry optimization algorithm from various possible starting structures at the B3LYP/6-31G(d,p) level.[S6?S8] In these calculations, the solvent chloroform was also simulated within the SMD framework. To ensure consistency with UV-Vis absorption and CD experiments, ground state optimizations and time-dependent DFT (TD-DFT) calculations were conducted, simulating the solvent 1,1,2,2-tetrachloroethane with 1,2-dichloroethane (汍 = 10.36) as a solvent within the Polarizable Continuum Model (PCM) framework.[S9] The calculated frontier orbitals of Diphane-5 are displayed in Figure S31. Frequency calculations were performed with no imaginary frequency found for the optimized molecular geometry. TD-DFT calculations were conducted using optimized molecular geometry, considering the first 50 transitions (singlet:triplet = 50:50). The solvent 1,2-dichloroethane was simulated within PCM framework. Specifically, TD-DFT calculations were performed at the B3LYP/6-311G(d,p) level.[S10] Electronic transitions were visualized using GaussSum 3.0,[S11] setting the full width half maximum (FWHM) to 2500 cm?1 for predicted UV-vis absorption spectra, and the 考 value is set to 0.5 eV for predicted CD spectra. Excited state hole-electron analysis was carrying out using Multiwfn 3.8 (dev).[S12]  3. Synthesis of Precursors and Diphane-5 The syntheses of all chemical compounds are described as follows. Diphane-5 was synthesized by the condensation of aldehyde and amide and following keto-enol tautomerization according to our previous literature.[S13] 2,4,6-Trihydroxybenzene-1,3,5-tricarbaldehyde (TP), tris(N-salicylideneaniline) (TSAN) and 1,3,5-tris(3,5-dibromophenyl)benzene (compound 1) were synthesized according to the literature S6  procedure.[S14?S16] 1H and 13C NMR spectra of all compounds are listed after their synthetic procedures and proton assignments are given in corresponding spectra in Section 4 and 12.
